title: Do items get returned to a lendor if you file for bankrupsy>??
question_tags: Debt collection for businesses,Chapter 7 bankruptcy for businesses,Chapter 13 bankruptcy for businesses,Liquidating business assets,Business real estate,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Mortgage lien,Lien,Bankruptcy liquidation,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan,Real estate and bankruptcy,Home mortgage,Real estate,Business,Car loan
answers: I agree with my colleagues above. If you have property that is secured by a lien, you will need to discuss your various options with an attorney.

It depends on the item and depends on if the item was included as collateral for the loan (called a "secured loan")

If you purchased too many luxuries over the previous 6 months, then there is a chance you will have to return the money, or that you will still owe the creditor if you purchased more than $500 in luxuries from any individual creditor.

Things like a car will have to be returned unless you want to, and can keep making, payments.

If you bought an item at Best Buy or Kay Jewelers on their store card you may find them asking you to return the item or pay for it. I have seen them ask for iPhones, cameras, GPS, etc. I have seen other creditor ask for the return of furniture . The question is how do you respond to these request. If you do not care about the item just tell them to come retrieve them. They usually never do, end of story. If the item is important to you you could try to reach an agreement to pay less than is owed.

Depending on what chapter of Bankruptcy you file items that you may own do not get returned to the lender. In a Chapter 7 liquidation Bankruptcy secured debts can be reaffirmed with the lender which allows you to get the property & continue making the regular payments. In Chapter 13 Bankruptcy secured debts ate either paid in the bankruptcy or directly paid o the creditor. With either Bankruptcy Chapter you can keep your secured property, by either reaffirming the debt in a Chapter 7 or by continuing making the payments to the creditor directly or through the Chapter 13 Trustee. With either Chapter there are multiple options and variables to each. The best thing to do is to discuss your options with a Bankruptcy Attorney prior to filing.

It is not entirely clear whatyou are asking, but I believe you are asking if you can keep property secured by a bank's claim, such as a car loan or home mortgage. The basic answer is that all secured portions of debt survive bankruptcy, which means that you will have to pay for the items you intend to keep in some fashion or another. For example, you cannot expect to "erase" debt on your car and not pay the payments, but still keep it. You either have to keep making the payments or file a chapter that allows you to pay only what the car is worth. For example, let's say you have a car worth $10K but you owe $15K on it. There are chapters that will allow you to pay the $10K and respread the note over as much as 36 to 60 months (depending upon your jurisdiction and the circumstances) -- often at a lower interest rate than what you may be paying.

If this sounds confusing, it is: I highly suggest you find competent local bankruptcy counsel to help you decide what options are best for your situation.
